text: <@U1L0RBZFH> in the context of the practicum, a database (e.g. MySQL) is going to help the most  for making fast queries, specifically when you're looking for small pieces of the entire dataset.  If you're consistently reading in the entire dataset, then the database won't help much, but it won't hurt performance either.  It's a good learning experience either way, but a team has to manage how steep the total learning curve is for everyone.  for your specific practicum, I would imagine a database would be worthwhile to utilize for speeding up queries, but not essential.  If you're using SAS, it would be just as well to use SAS7BDAT formatted data with SAS indexes where appropriate in order to get faster query times.

<@U1L0RBZFH> regarding using SAS7BDAT's instead of putting things into MySQL, for example:  you can still use proc sql  to do SQL queries on the SAS7BDAT even if you're not using a proper database management system like MySQL.   i.e. the benefits of SQL are available to you in either case (MySQL, or SAS native format data sets)
